title: Water and Sun Safety
subject: Health and Physical Education
substrand: Safety, Risk Management and Protective Behaviours
description: This topic explores water safety, swimming skills, recognising and responding to aquatic emergencies, sun protection, and skin cancer prevention. Students develop knowledge and skills for safe enjoyment of Australian outdoor environments.
curriculumDescriptions: Plan, rehearse and evaluate strategies for managing situations where their own or others' safety may be at risk
Investigate and select strategies to promote health, safety and wellbeing

contentSections.title: Water Safety Rules
contentSections.content: Water can be fun but also dangerous. Important rules to follow are: always swim with an adult watching you, swim between the red and yellow flags at beaches, never run near pools, don't push people in the water, learn to swim, and ask before going near water. If you get tired or scared in the water, float on your back and call for help. Never swim alone.

contentSections.title: When to Get Help at Water
contentSections.content: If someone is in trouble in the water, don't jump in to save them - you could get in trouble too. Instead, shout for help from a lifeguard or adult. Look for something that floats (like a pool noodle, ball, or life ring) that you can throw to them. Call Triple Zero (000) in an emergency. Tell the person to float and stay calm while help comes.

contentSections.title: Protecting Your Skin from the Sun
contentSections.content: The sun sends invisible rays called UV that can damage your skin. Too much sun causes sunburn, which hurts and can make you sick. The SunSmart message helps you remember how to protect yourself: Slip on protective clothing, Slop on SPF 30+ sunscreen, Slap on a hat, Seek shade, Slide on sunglasses. Doing all five gives the best protection.

contentSections.title: Sun Safety Habits
contentSections.content: The sun is strongest in the middle of the day, usually between 10am and 2pm. This is when you need the most protection. Put sunscreen on before going outside and put more on every two hours. Wear a hat that covers your face, ears and neck. If you can, play in the shade instead of direct sun. Check the UV rating on weather apps - when it's 3 or above, you need protection.

relational.stem: Explain why you shouldn't jump in the water to save someone who is drowning.
relational.modelResponse: You shouldn't jump in because the person who is drowning might grab onto you and pull you under too. This would mean two people need rescuing instead of one. The person is panicking and might push you underwater without meaning to. It's safer to throw something that floats, reach out with something long like a pole, or call for help from a lifeguard or adult who knows how to rescue safely.
relational.rubric: Explains the danger of becoming a second victim. Shows understanding that drowning people can pull rescuers under. Suggests safer alternatives.

extendedAbstract.stem: Think about why Australia has so many drownings and so much skin cancer compared to other countries. What is it about Australia that makes these things such big problems?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Australia has high rates of drowning and skin cancer because of its environment and lifestyle. We are surrounded by water - beaches, pools, rivers, and dams are everywhere, so people spend more time in and around water. Our weather is warm, so people swim more months of the year. For skin cancer, Australia has very strong UV rays because of our position near the equator and our clear skies. Many Australians have fair skin because their families came from Europe, where the sun is weaker. Also, Australians love being outdoors at the beach, playing sports, and swimming. These are great things about living here, but they mean we need to be extra careful about water and sun safety.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies Australia's unique environmental factors. Connects lifestyle/culture to exposure risks. Shows understanding of why these are particular issues for Australia.

contentSections.title: Understanding Water Hazards
contentSections.content: Different water environments have different hazards. Pools: depth changes, slippery surfaces, diving in shallow water. Beaches: rips, waves, rocks, marine stingers. Rivers and dams: hidden depths, cold water, currents, underwater objects. All water: tiredness, getting cold, alcohol, not being able to swim. Knowing the hazards helps you stay safe. Always check conditions before entering water and never swim alone or when tired.

contentSections.title: Understanding Rips
contentSections.content: Rips are channels of water flowing from the beach back out to sea. They form when waves push water onto the beach and it needs to flow back out. Signs of a rip include: darker, calmer-looking water; rippled or choppy surface when water around is calm; foam or debris moving out to sea; a gap in the breaking waves. If caught in a rip: don't panic, don't fight the current, float and stay calm, let it carry you out past the waves, then swim parallel to the beach to escape it, raise your hand to signal for help.

contentSections.title: Basic Rescue Principles
contentSections.content: If someone is in trouble in water, remember: Reach, Throw, Don't Go. Reach: extend something like a pole, towel, or branch for them to grab while you stay on land. Throw: throw a flotation device, rope, or anything that floats. Don't Go: entering the water to rescue is dangerous unless you're trained. Call for help immediately - shout for lifeguards, ask others to call Triple Zero. Keep talking to the person to help them stay calm.

contentSections.title: Building Sun Safety Habits
contentSections.content: Consistent sun protection requires building habits. Check the UV index daily - protection is needed when it's 3 or above. Apply sunscreen 20 minutes before going outside so it soaks in. Reapply every two hours, or after swimming or sweating. Choose SPF 30+ or 50+ sunscreen that is broad spectrum (protects against both UVA and UVB). Pack a hat and sunglasses as part of your routine. Make sun protection automatic, like putting on clothes.

analyse.question: Analyse why swimming in a river or dam can be more dangerous than swimming at a patrolled beach.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple factors. Rivers/dams: no lifeguards, hidden dangers underwater, cold water (even in summer), currents may not be visible, no flags showing safe areas, depths change unpredictably. Patrolled beaches: lifeguards watching, flagged areas checked for safety, rescue equipment available, conditions assessed. Strong responses connect these factors to show why risk is different.

evaluate.question: Evaluate whether checking the UV index on your phone each morning is a useful sun safety habit.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should evaluate this habit positively. Benefits: quick and easy, helps plan what protection to take, UV varies day to day so checking helps you know how careful to be, helps decide when to seek shade. Limitations: need to remember to check, need to act on the information, UV also varies during the day. Overall: a useful habit as part of a routine. Strong responses acknowledge it's one part of an overall approach.

Recognises it needs to be acted upon to be useful

relational.stem: Explain why you should reapply sunscreen every two hours and after swimming.
relational.modelResponse: Sunscreen needs reapplying because its effectiveness decreases over time. After two hours, the chemicals that block UV rays break down and stop working as well. When you swim, even 'water resistant' sunscreen washes off gradually, reducing protection. Sweating, towelling off, and rubbing also remove sunscreen from your skin. If you don't reapply, you're getting less and less protection even though you put some on earlier. The initial application protects you for a while, but maintaining protection requires regular reapplication.
relational.rubric: Explains that sunscreen effectiveness decreases over time. Shows understanding that water and sweat remove sunscreen. Connects reapplication to maintaining protection.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider why drowning is one of the leading causes of death for young people in Australia despite widespread swimming education. What might explain this, and what could be done differently?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Despite swimming education, drowning remains a major cause of death because of several factors beyond just knowing how to swim. Risk-taking increases in adolescence - young people may overestimate their abilities, swim in dangerous places, or take risks for excitement. Alcohol and drugs are involved in many drownings. Some drownings happen in situations where swimming skill doesn't help - rock fishing, floods, or car accidents in water. Supervision decreases as young people become more independent. Some populations have less access to swimming lessons. What might help: education beyond just swimming skills to include water safety decision-making, understanding personal limits, and how alcohol affects water safety. Also addressing risky behaviours specifically and ensuring all young Australians have access to water safety education.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies factors beyond swimming ability. Recognises risk-taking and decision-making as important. Shows understanding that drowning prevention requires more than swimming skills. Suggests meaningful improvements.

contentSections.title: Analysing Aquatic Risks
contentSections.content: Different aquatic environments present different risks requiring different approaches. Beaches: rips, waves, marine life, changing conditions. Pools: diving injuries, drain entrapment, glass hazards. Rivers: hidden currents, cold water, underwater objects. Dams and lakes: cold water at depth, no visibility, unknown hazards. Rock platforms: waves washing people off, slippery surfaces. Flood water: contamination, hidden hazards, strong currents. Analysing the specific risks of each environment allows appropriate precautions and decisions about whether to enter the water.

contentSections.title: The Drowning Chain
contentSections.content: Drowning rarely happens suddenly - it usually follows a chain of events: lack of awareness (not knowing the risks) leads to lack of education (not having skills to recognise or respond), leads to lack of supervision (no one watching), leads to lack of barriers (nothing preventing access), leads to lack of rescue response (can't be saved in time). Breaking any link prevents drowning. For teenagers, common links include: underestimating risks, overestimating swimming ability, alcohol/drug impairment, peer pressure to take risks, and swimming in unpatrolled locations. Understanding this helps identify where to intervene.

contentSections.title: Understanding Skin Cancer
contentSections.content: Australia has the highest skin cancer rates in the world. Risk factors include: UV exposure (especially during childhood and adolescence when skin is more vulnerable), skin type (fair skin burns more easily), family history, and history of sunburn. Melanoma is the most dangerous type - it can spread to other parts of the body. Other skin cancers (BCC, SCC) are also serious and can require surgery. Most skin cancers are preventable through sun protection. UV damage is cumulative - it adds up over your lifetime, so protection during youth is especially important.

contentSections.title: Comprehensive Sun Protection
contentSections.content: Effective sun protection combines multiple strategies. Timing: avoid peak UV hours (10am-2pm) when possible. Shade: seek or create shade, but remember UV reflects off surfaces. Clothing: UPF-rated clothing, hats with brims, sunglasses. Sunscreen: SPF 50+ broad spectrum, applied properly (most people apply too little), reapplied every 2 hours. For outdoor activities, planning ahead ensures you have protection available. The UV Index helps guide when protection is needed - in Australia, protection is usually needed most of the year, not just summer.

analyse.question: Analyse why sun damage during childhood and adolescence is particularly significant for lifetime skin cancer risk.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple factors. Young skin may be more vulnerable to UV damage. Sun exposure in early life contributes disproportionately to lifetime risk. Sunburn in childhood/adolescence is particularly associated with melanoma. More years ahead means more time for damage to develop into cancer. Sun behaviours established young persist. Australia's high UV means even 'normal' outdoor childhood involves significant exposure. Strong responses connect biological and behavioural factors.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the effectiveness of the SunSmart program in Australia. Consider what evidence exists and what challenges remain.

Remaining challenges: melanoma rates still high, behaviour-attitude gap (knowing but not doing), protection often insufficient, some populations have lower sun safety. Strong responses balance successes with remaining work needed.

relational.stem: Explain how breaking different links in the drowning chain can prevent drowning in different ways.
relational.modelResponse: Different links in the drowning chain can be broken with different strategies, each preventing drowning in its own way. Breaking 'lack of awareness' through education means people recognise risks before entering dangerous situations. Breaking 'lack of supervision' through active watching means someone notices trouble quickly. Breaking 'lack of barriers' through pool fencing means young children can't access water unsupervised. Breaking 'lack of rescue response' through lifeguards and rescue training means when incidents occur, people can be saved. The chain shows drowning prevention isn't just one thing - it's multiple layers of protection. If one layer fails, another might still prevent death. This is why comprehensive approaches are most effective.
relational.rubric: Explains how different links can be broken by different interventions. Shows understanding that multiple layers provide better protection. Connects specific interventions to specific links.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how climate change might affect water and sun safety risks in Australia over the coming decades. What adaptations might be needed?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Climate change will affect water and sun safety in multiple ways. Hotter temperatures may increase pool and beach use, increasing drowning exposure. More extreme weather events (floods, storms) create dangerous water conditions. Warmer ocean temperatures may change marine life distribution (stingers moving south). UV may change with ozone fluctuations. Heatwaves combined with UV create compound risks. Flood waters are particularly dangerous and may become more common. Adaptations needed include: infrastructure changes (shade in public spaces, cool refuges), updated public messaging linking climate and safety, emergency response capacity for floods, rethinking outdoor activities during extreme heat/UV, and research on changing risks. Beach safety organisations may need to adapt to new conditions and locations of risk.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies specific climate impacts on water and sun safety. Proposes meaningful adaptations. Shows sophisticated understanding of interconnected environmental and health risks.

contentSections.title: Analysing Drowning Data
contentSections.content: Australia experiences approximately 280 drownings annually, plus many more non-fatal drownings with lasting effects. Analysis reveals patterns: males account for about 80% of drownings; peak age is 25-34 (often alcohol-related) and over 65 (health events); inland waterways (rivers, dams, lakes) are highest risk locations; Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have higher drowning rates; people from culturally diverse backgrounds face elevated risks; rock fishing is particularly dangerous. Understanding these patterns helps target prevention efforts. Behind each statistic are preventable tragedies.

contentSections.title: Evaluating Water Safety Programs
contentSections.content: Australia has various water safety programs. Surf lifesaving provides patrols and education. Royal Life Saving programs include swimming lessons, public awareness, and research. School swimming programs vary by state. Pool fencing laws have significantly reduced toddler drownings. Evaluating programs requires considering: reach (who do they contact?), effectiveness (do they change behaviour/outcomes?), equity (do some populations miss out?), sustainability (can they continue?). Some successful approaches include targeted programs for at-risk groups, community champions from within those groups, and environmental interventions like fencing.

contentSections.title: Skin Cancer Prevention Policy
contentSections.content: Australia leads in skin cancer prevention policy. SunSmart programs have changed behaviour around sun protection. Shade policies in schools and workplaces require shade provision. Solarium bans prohibit commercial sunbeds. Occupational regulations require outdoor worker protection. The UV Index has become part of weather reports. Despite these successes, melanoma rates remain high in older Australians (damage from decades ago), while reducing in younger generations. Evaluation shows policy works but takes generations to show full effect. Current challenges include reaching resistant populations and ensuring consistent behaviour change.

contentSections.title: Advocacy for Community Safety
contentSections.content: Young people can advocate for improved water and sun safety. Water safety advocacy might include: campaigning for improved facilities, supporting programs for at-risk groups, promoting safe behaviours among peers, or volunteering with surf lifesaving. Sun safety advocacy might include: improving shade at schools or public spaces, challenging tanning culture, promoting UV index checking, or supporting workplace policies. Effective advocacy uses evidence (data on local issues), tells stories (personal impact), engages stakeholders, and proposes solutions. Youth voice is powerful in behaviour change campaigns.

analyse.question: Analyse why Australia's skin cancer rates remain high despite decades of successful sun safety campaigns.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple factors. Lag effect: current melanomas often result from damage decades ago before campaigns. Ageing population: more time for cumulative damage to manifest. Behaviour gaps: knowing doesn't always mean doing; consistent protection is hard. Outdoor lifestyle: Australians still have high sun exposure. Inequitable reach: some populations may not receive or respond to messages. Indoor tanning: past solarium use. Strong responses balance campaign successes with remaining challenges.

Against: swimming alone isn't sufficient (water safety attitudes matter more); some programs are low quality; doesn't reach everyone (absentees, home schooled); cost and logistics challenging. Evidence: populations with higher swimming rates have lower child drowning but adolescent/adult drowning involves behaviour more than skill. Strong responses balance multiple considerations.

relational.stem: Explain how environmental controls, education, and supervision work together in drowning prevention.
relational.modelResponse: Environmental controls, education, and supervision create layers of protection that complement each other. Environmental controls (pool fencing, patrolled beach areas, signage) physically reduce risk without requiring individual action - they protect everyone including those who don't have education or supervision. Education gives people knowledge and skills to make good decisions and recognise danger, but only works if people act on what they learn. Supervision provides immediate response capability but can't prevent all incidents and isn't always available. Together they create multiple layers: a child might be saved by a pool fence even if unsupervised, a swimmer with education avoids a rip even without a lifeguard, and a lifeguard rescues someone despite inadequate education. If one layer fails, others may still prevent drowning.
relational.rubric: Explains how each type of intervention works. Shows understanding of how layers complement each other. Identifies that multiple layers provide better protection when one fails.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how Australia's approach to water and sun safety might inform other countries with different contexts. What elements are transferable and what would need adaptation?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Australia has developed strong water and sun safety approaches that could inform other countries, but adaptation is essential. Transferable elements: the principle of multi-layered prevention, the concept of the drowning chain, Sun-Smart messaging structures, research and evaluation approaches, volunteer-based lifesaving models, and policy frameworks like pool fencing. Elements needing adaptation: specific hazards differ (tropical beaches vs rivers vs cold water), cultural contexts affect messaging and behaviour, infrastructure and resources vary significantly, some populations have different skin types and cancer risks, and climate affects both water usage and UV exposure. The underlying principles (evidence-based prevention, multiple intervention layers, targeted approaches for at-risk groups, combining environment, education, and enforcement) transfer, while specific programs need local development. Australia's experience shows long-term commitment works, but global application must respect local context.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies transferable principles versus context-specific elements. Shows sophisticated understanding of adaptation needs. Recognises that principles may transfer while specific programs need local development.

contentSections.title: Global Drowning Research
contentSections.content: Drowning kills over 230,000 people globally each year, with 90% of deaths in low and middle-income countries. Research identifies universal risk factors (age, gender, alcohol) and context-specific factors (exposure type, cultural factors). Intervention research shows effectiveness of pool fencing, swim training in endemic areas, and rescue services, but implementation varies enormously. The WHO Global Report on Drowning has raised awareness, but resources follow burden unevenly - high-income countries invest heavily while most deaths occur in low-resource settings. Research challenges include underreporting, especially in developing countries, and difficulty measuring non-fatal incidents.

contentSections.title: Skin Cancer: A Global Perspective
contentSections.content: Australia and New Zealand have the world's highest melanoma rates, but skin cancer is increasing globally. The relationship between UV exposure and cancer is complex - intense intermittent exposure (sunburn) may matter more than total dose for melanoma. Fair-skinned populations historically from low-UV regions (European ancestry) are at highest risk globally. Climate change may affect future UV patterns. Prevention research shows sun protection works, but implementation remains challenging. Tanning culture persists despite knowledge of risks. Economic analyses show prevention is cost-effective given treatment costs. Research frontiers include understanding genetic susceptibility and developing better early detection.

contentSections.title: International Approaches
contentSections.content: Countries approach water and sun safety differently based on context. The Netherlands, with canals throughout, achieves low drowning through universal early swimming education. Bangladesh has reduced child drowning through community supervision programs. High-income countries often rely on infrastructure (pool fencing, patrolled beaches) that isn't feasible everywhere. Nordic countries have high UV awareness despite lower UV levels. Low and middle-income countries face different challenges - infrastructure cost, competing health priorities, and different water exposure patterns. Evaluating international approaches requires understanding context - what works depends on resources, culture, and exposure patterns.

contentSections.title: Emerging Challenges
contentSections.content: Emerging challenges require new thinking. Climate change brings flooding (different drowning patterns), changed UV (ozone recovery and climate effects), and population movement (people in unfamiliar environments). Ageing populations face higher drowning risk from medical events in water. Migration means more people learning to swim later in life in unfamiliar environments. Technology offers opportunities (apps, drones for rescue, UV sensors) but also risks (distraction). Mental health intersects with water (intentional self-harm is a proportion of drowning). Addressing emerging challenges requires research, adaptable programs, and willingness to innovate.

analyse.question: Analyse the implementation challenges that may explain why proven drowning prevention interventions (like pool fencing) aren't universally adopted even in countries that can afford them.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple implementation challenges. Political: fencing laws require legislation and may face opposition. Economic: individual cost barriers even in wealthy countries. Enforcement: laws need monitoring and consequences. Behaviour: gates propped open, maintenance neglected. Rental properties: split incentives between owners and renters. Existing pools: retrofitting is harder than new construction. Public perception: some see it as overreach. Strong responses use implementation science concepts.

evaluate.question: Evaluate whether resources for drowning prevention globally should be reallocated to where the burden is highest (low-income countries) or whether wealthy countries should continue to invest in reducing their lower absolute numbers.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should engage with this ethical question. Arguments for reallocation: burden is highest in low-income countries, cost-effectiveness is often better there, human life has equal value regardless of location. Arguments for maintaining wealthy country investment: moral responsibility to citizens, expertise development that can transfer, declining investment may reverse gains. Possible middle positions: increase global funding rather than reallocation, technology and knowledge transfer, aid for prevention in developing countries. Strong responses engage with both efficiency and equity considerations.

relational.stem: Explain why drowning prevention interventions that work in high-income countries may need significant adaptation for low-income contexts.
relational.modelResponse: Interventions need adaptation because context shapes what's feasible and effective. High-income country approaches often rely on: expensive infrastructure (pool fencing, patrolled beaches), professional services (lifeguards, emergency response), universal swimming programs in heated pools, and technology. Low-income contexts may have: different water exposure (open water rather than pools), limited infrastructure, different cultural factors, many competing health priorities, and less formal systems. What works in Australia (surf lifesaving volunteers) isn't transferable to Bangladeshi village ponds. Effective adaptation keeps principles (layers of protection, community involvement) while changing methods (community supervision instead of professional lifeguards, natural water training instead of pool lessons). Implementation must match resources, culture, and exposure patterns.
relational.rubric: Identifies why high-income approaches may not transfer. Shows understanding of context-specific factors. Explains how adaptation maintains principles while changing methods.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how advancements in genetic understanding might transform skin cancer prevention in the future. What opportunities and ethical challenges might arise?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Genetic advances could transform skin cancer prevention. Opportunities: genetic testing could identify those at highest risk, enabling personalised prevention (some need more protection than others); understanding genetic repair mechanisms could lead to treatments that enhance natural protection; pharmacological agents might eventually supplement physical protection. Early detection could improve with genetic markers. This could make prevention more effective by targeting resources where most needed. Ethical challenges: genetic privacy concerns if testing becomes routine; potential for discrimination by insurers or employers; equity if genetic services aren't universally accessible; risk of fatalism if people believe genetics determines outcomes; possible reduction in population-wide messages if focus shifts to high-risk individuals; commercialisation of genetic information. There's also the risk of over-reliance on future genetic solutions delaying current behavioural interventions. Genetic advances offer promise but require ethical frameworks to ensure equitable benefit.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies specific opportunities from genetic advances. Anticipates meaningful ethical challenges. Shows sophisticated understanding of personalised prevention possibilities. Considers equity implications.
